repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Second payment system and bank
            modernization project

abstracts.cdata!:
The results profile talks about finance,
            banking, and payment services of Vietnam. The Second Payment
            System and Bank Modernization Project (PSBM2) significantly
            improved the speed and reliability of interbank payments in
            Vietnam from two weeks in 2005 to within the day, with
            exponential growth of financial transactions nationwide. The
            participating banks settled customer fund transfers within
            minutes as compared to days in 2004-05. Centralized funds
            and customer management strengthened project entities’ risk
            management capacity. Several banks can offer eBanking
            services to customers now (159,000 eBanking customers and
            412,360 instant messaging customers).The PSBM2 brought about
            several verifiable economic benefits in the development of a
            modern financial sector infrastructure, access to finance
            and improved banking operations. Based on the positive
            experience of the two PSBM projects, the government has
            recently adopted a strategy to promote a non-cash economy in
            Vietnam to further develop financial sector infrastructure
            and improve access to finance.

            Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Payment System
            and Bank Modernization Project for Vietnam were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            low or negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory and
            borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: an important lesson learned is flexibility
            in designing the overall system architecture and
            implementation sequencing for Information Technology
            (IT)-based/IT-driven projects in the banking and probably
            other sectors of an emerging market economy that is
            experiencing fast changing the industry and technology. A
            flexible overall design alone cannot guarantee the success.
            Detailed technical analysis is needed to develop an
            implementable project implementation plan. Reengineering of
            main operational systems in an institution often leads to
            major institutional changes. Technical competency of
            implementing agencies and of Bank task team is critical.
            This is a recurrent lesson almost in all the Bank-financed
            projects. The strong ownership of Second Payment System and
            Bank Modernization Project (PSBM2) by the government and the
            implementing agencies could not be maintained without the
            positive experience.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Second Payment System and Bank
            Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Payment
            System and Bank Modernization Project for Vietnam is to
            continue assisting the government and the banks in their
            efforts to modernize the financial sector through further
            development of the financial sector infrastructure to
            support economic growth, and achievement of the poverty
            reduction targets set out in the government's
            Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS).
            The project has the following two components: Component 1)
            the main activities of this component include (i) upgrading
            hardware and installing new software to expand processing
            capability and strengthen interconnection, system, and
            physical security; (ii) consultant support of project
            implementation such as advisory services on the required
            legal and regulatory environment; and (iii) staff training.
            Component 2) focuses on the urgent need to rollout the
            solutions to mitigate the high operational risk of running
            two parallel, but completely different systems, and to
            enhance the system and physical security of the new facilities.
